screens.headline: This is the trade beginners start with
screens.text: Buying a call is the simplest bullish trade in options. When you think a stock will POP, this gives you leveraged upside with defined risk. Let's learn to do it right.

screens.headline: What is 'Buying a Call'?
screens.text: Buying a call = paying a premium for the RIGHT to buy 100 shares at your strike price by expiration. You profit when stock goes UP above your breakeven. Max loss = premium paid. Max profit = unlimited as stock rises.

cards.example: Buy to open 1 AAPL $180 call for $5.00 = you're long 1 call contract. You want the stock to go UP.

cards.definition: Strike price equals current stock price
cards.example: Stock at $100, buying the $100 call = ATM. Balanced risk/reward. Most liquid.

cards.definition: Strike price above current stock (for calls)
cards.example: Stock at $100, buying $110 call = OTM. Cheaper but needs bigger move. Higher risk/reward.

screens.headline: Think of it like buying a lottery ticket - but smarter
screens.text: Your friend has playoff tickets he might sell. The game is in 3 weeks. Ticket face value is $100, but if the team makes the finals, they'll be worth $500...

reveal_sections.label: You pay $20 for the OPTION to buy at $100
reveal_sections.content: Your friend agrees: you can buy his tickets for $100 anytime in the next 3 weeks. You paid $20 for this privilege.

reveal_sections.label: Team makes the finals (tickets now $500)
reveal_sections.content: You exercise: buy at $100, sell at $500. Profit = $400 - $20 = $380. That's a 1,900% return on your $20!

reveal_sections.label: Team loses (tickets worth $50)
reveal_sections.content: You don't exercise. Why buy at $100 when they're worth $50? You walk away, losing only your $20 deposit. You didn't overpay for bad tickets.

reveal_sections.label: This is buying a call option
reveal_sections.content: Premium = $20. Strike = $100. Expiration = 3 weeks. You profit when value exceeds strike + premium. Max loss = $20.

screens.question: When should you buy a call option?
options: When you think the stock will go down
When you're bullish and expect upward movement
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! Buy calls when you're BULLISH (expect price to rise). Best scenarios: upcoming catalysts (earnings, product launches), technical breakouts, or sector momentum. You're betting on upward movement.
screens.explanation_wrong: Remember: CALLS profit when stock goes UP. You buy calls when you're bullish and expect upward price movement. Think: earnings beat, product launch, technical breakout, sector rotation into your stock.

screens.question: NVDA at $500. You're very bullish due to AI boom. Which call makes most sense for moderate risk?
screens.explanation_correct: Smart! Slightly OTM ($520 vs $500) = cheap but realistic. 60 days = enough time for AI momentum to play out. Not too risky (far OTM) or expensive (deep ITM). This is the 'Goldilocks zone' for directional calls.
screens.explanation_wrong: For moderate risk: avoid far OTM strikes (need massive moves) and very short expirations (need instant moves). The $520 call in 60 days gives you room to be right with a manageable premium. Think balanced: probability meets reward.

screens.question: You bought a call for $300. Stock moved UP 5%, but your call is DOWN to $250. Why?
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! Stock moved UP, but not enough to overcome time decay. This is why buying short-dated OTM calls is risky - you can be RIGHT about direction but still lose to theta. Lesson: stock needs to move MORE than decay eats.
screens.explanation_wrong: You experienced the option trap: stock went up 5%, but your option decayed $50 in time value. If you bought short-dated or far OTM, delta (price sensitivity) is low, so small stock moves don't help much. Meanwhile, theta bleeds you daily.

screens.question: META at $300. You buy 2 call contracts with $320 strike for $8 each. META goes to $340. What's your TOTAL profit in dollars? (No commas or $ sign)
screens.hint: Profit = (Stock - Strike - Premium) √ó 100 √ó Number of Contracts
screens.explanation: Stock at $340, strike $320 = $20 intrinsic. Minus $8 premium = $12 profit per share √ó 100 = $1,200 per contract √ó 2 contracts = $2,400 total profit. Watch that √ó100 and remember you bought 2!

screens.question: Your call is up 100% (doubled). Expiration is in 30 days. Stock has been choppy. What do professional traders typically do?
options: Hold until expiration - might go higher!
Sell half, lock in some profit
Double down and buy more calls
Exercise the option and buy shares
screens.explanation_correct: This is smart risk management! Sell half, lock in 100% gain on that portion, let the rest ride for free. Now you can't lose - your remaining position is 'house money.' Professionals take profits on the way up.
screens.explanation_wrong: Rule #1: You can't go broke taking profits. Rule #2: Markets can reverse quickly. Selling half at 100% means you've locked in gains while keeping upside exposure. The remaining calls now have zero cost basis. This is professional trade management.

cards.back: When bullish + catalyst expected. Best: earnings, product launches, sector momentum. Avoid: choppy markets, no clear catalyst, high IV before earnings.
Conservative: ATM or slightly OTM. Aggressive: 10-20% OTM. Rule: Give yourself a 60%+ probability of profit. Check delta (0.5 = 50% chance of ITM).
Take profits at 50-100% gain. Cut losses at -50%. Don't hold to expiration unless deep ITM. Time decay accelerates in final 30 days.

screens.badge_description: You know how to buy calls strategically!
screens.celebration_message: Awesome! You've mastered the most popular options trade. Next: learning the opposite - profiting from downward moves.
